resist arrest

Columbia
 
 By Langston Hughes
 
 Columbia, 
 My dear girl, 
 You really haven't been a virgin for so long. 
 It's ludicrous to keep up the pretext. 
 You're terribly involved in world assignations 
 And everybody knows it. 
 You've slept with all the big powers 
 In military uniforms, 
 And you've taken the sweet life 
 Of all the little brown fellows 
 In loincloths and cotton trousers. 
 When they've resisted, 
 You've yelled, "Rape," 
 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
 Being one of the world's big vampires, 
 Why don't you come on out and say so 
 Like Japan, and England, and France, 
 And all the other nymphomaniacs of power 
 Who've long since dropped their 
 Smoke screens of innocence 
 To sit frankly on a bed of bombs? 
 
 * Columbia is the first popular and poetic name for the United States of America; it is also the origin of the name for the District of Columbia, the federal district which is coextensive with the federal capital, Washington. Columbia is a feminine form derived from Christopher Columbus, one of the first Europeans to explore the Americas after the Vikings. The moniker dates from before the American Revolution in 1776 but fell out of use in the early 20th century.

My daughter was admitted into Harvard based on her merit, not on her wealth. It was not so with Bill Gates, though I grant that he did have the intelligence and necessary abilities to gain admittance into Harvard.

 
 Oh, well, your daughter is a greedy scumbag. How dare she try to make something of her life? How dare she? You're just making it more and more apparent to me that you're advocating equality of outcome, not equality of oppurtunity. What does she do for a living now? Does she make you proud? If you're so satisfied with her progress in life, then why are you screaming for the government to take her money? If not, are you ashamed of her success? Are you ashamed of her greed? Are you ashamed that she worked? 
 
 For that matter, if she inherited your political veiws, does she advocate the same policies you do? Does she want the government to take her money, like a thousand other XXXXXX in Hollywood? You see Oprah Wimfrey, Michael the Hutt, and Nosy O'Donnell stepping up and saying "Here I am! Come take my money!"
 
 Or the other conclusion is that your daughter's a failure. Despite her greed-based education that you seem so proud of, she ultimately ended up flipping burgers, collecting welfare, or selling herself on street corners. You feel that life might be worth living if the government took from people who actually work and give money to the former class clowns and welfare slugs. I find so ironic when you say that rich people lack patriotism because they pay taxes that you find loose, yet you scream for the government to lower your taxes.
 
 I am a middle-class citizen. I don't live in a masion and I don't have a garage full of brand-new cars. But I am one of the few who still completely understand and follow the doctrine Ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country. You, comrade, have forgotten that long, long ago. I can tell by the left's screaming of "Give me money!!!" like a foul taste in my mouth. You're like a typical American that you see these days; you live in a fantasy world and you think your life sucks so bad. You scream and yell that your healthcare benefits aren't as good as you want them to be when you don't even give the millions who don't have healthcare a second thought. You're spoiled, just like everyone else in this country. You expect your government to be a nanny rather than a leader, and when it tries to be a leader you make it a scapegoat.

 Let's put it this way:
 
 You go to the store and you buy stuff.
 
 The CEO of the store you bought something from makes 200k a year.
 
 Being the CEO of the store is a stressful job, but the 200k is worth it. 
 
 You accuse the CEO of being greedy when in reality, he's simply sacrificing some free time to be successful in life.
 
 Then you vote some guy in office who lowers his wages to 100k a year.
 
 The CEO is disappointed because the government just cut his paycheck in half. So he's working just as much, but for less money. 
 
 One day, the CEO says "&!#? this!! I don't wanna be CEO anymore!"
 
 The company goes bankrupt, and you don't get to go to the store to buy stuff.
 
 Was it clear enough that time?

 Let's put it a different way.
 
 The $200K he is making is theft pure and simple. It's money stolen from the workers who make his operation go.
 
 Huff and puff as he might, without them, all the entrepeneurial skill in the world is not going to get a ton of coal out of the ground, move a single freight car full of merchandise, construct an automobile, or anything else.
 
 Yet, he sits like a king on a throne, living of the sweat and energy of others.

Columbia
 
 By Langston Hughes
 
 Columbia, 
 My dear girl, 
 You really haven't been a virgin for so long. 
 It's ludicrous to keep up the pretext. 
 You're terribly involved in world assignations 
 And everybody knows it. 
 You've slept with all the big powers 
 In military uniforms, 
 And you've taken the sweet life 
 Of all the little brown fellows 
 In loincloths and cotton trousers. 
 When they've resisted, 
 You've yelled, "Rape," 

 
 At the top of your voice
 And called for the middies
 To beat them up for not being gentlmen
 And liking your crooked painted mouth.
 (You must think the moons of Hawaii
 Disguise your ugliness.)
 Really,
 You're getting a little too old,
 Columbia,
 To be so naive, and so coy.
 
 
Being one of the world's big vampires, 
 Why don't you come on out and say so 
 Like Japan, and England, and France, 
 And all the other nymphomaniacs of power 
 Who've long since dropped their 
 Smoke screens of innocence 
 To sit frankly on a bed of bombs? 

 
 O, sweet mouth of India,
 And Africa,
 Manchuria, and Haiti.
 
 Columbia,
 You darling,
 Don't shoot!
 I'll kiss you!
 
 Uncollected Poems 1931-1940
